articles.title: APRIL 8TH 8 PM
articles.summary: This document outlines a busy schedule of astronomical events and meetings for April and May, primarily organized by the SJAA. It highlights multiple star parties at various parks, general meetings featuring speakers like John Briggs and Rob Fingerhut, and an introductory observational astronomy class. Key events also include the Bay-Area Astronomical Flea Market and Auction, a Fremont Peak Observatory open house, and the Riverside Telescope-Maker's Conference.

articles.title: FIELD OF VIEW
articles.summary: The article announces the 9th Annual SJAA/Bay Area Astronomical Auction and Swap Meet, scheduled for April 22. It emphasizes the informal nature of the Swap Meet, designed to encourage broad participation, and indicates that common questions will be addressed.
keywords: Bay Area Astronomical Auction and Swap Meet

articles.title: SWAP MEET RULES
articles.summary: This document outlines the rules for a swap meet, emphasizing that no registration is needed for participants or merchandise, even if items were previously registered for an auction. Key guidelines include specific buying/selling times (doors open 1:00 PM, selling starts 2:00 PM), a mandatory 10% commission on all sales to be settled before leaving, and provisions for silent bids or post-auction sales on the grounds. It also advises pre-registering items intended for auction and offers separate bidder numbers for those handling items on behalf of others.

articles.title: MEMBERSHIP CARD CONTEST
articles.summary: The article announces the conclusion of the Membership Card contest, congratulating winner Jack Zeiders, and details the upcoming 1989 Messier Marathon. The Marathon is scheduled for April 1/2, with members observing at Fremont Peak and Henry Coe Park, and participants are encouraged to contact Don Machholz for information and to report results.

articles.title: YOSEMITE STAR PARTY
articles.summary: The annual Yosemite Star Party is set for June 30 - July 1 at Glacier Point in Yosemite Park, promising five hours of moonless darkness each night. Attendance is limited to 30 people, and registration details will be announced in the May bulletin.

articles.title: The 9th ANNUAL Bay Area Astronomical Auction
articles.summary: The 9th Annual Bay Area Astronomical Auction, hosted by the San Jose Astronomical Association, is set for Saturday, April 22nd, at the Los Gatos Red Cross building. The event includes an afternoon swap-meet, a main auction, and a concurrent silent auction for larger items. Sellers can pre-register items, with a 10% commission benefiting public astronomy education.

articles.title: DIRECTIONS TO THE AUCTION
articles.summary: This document provides detailed directions to the 1989 Bay Area Astronomical Auction located at 16011 Los Gatos-Saratoga Rd, including specific routes and turning instructions. It outlines event details such as doors opening at 1:00 pm, a $1.00 registration donation, and the availability of refreshments. Additionally, the document includes a pre-registration form for bidders and sellers, indicating that the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) will complete specific fields.

articles.title: ASTRO-CLASS TO FEATURE TELESCOPES
articles.summary: This month's Introductory Astronomy class will feature a discussion on telescope types and their optimal uses, presented by Tom Ahl. Organizers are seeking volunteers to bring a variety of telescopes for display and demonstration. Additionally, Jack Zeiders is looking for color astrophotography slides for his constellation talks, recommending Konica 3200 film for long exposures.

articles.title: OPEN HOUSE AT FREMONT PEAK OBSERVATORY
articles.summary: The Fremont Peak Observatory Association (FPOA) is hosting an open house for Bay Area amateur astronomers on Saturday, May 6. Attendees will experience the observatory's freshly coated 30-inch telescope mirror and recent enhancements designed to improve observing comfort. Further details about the event are available on an enclosed information sheet.

articles.title: APRIL STARRY NIGHTS BY: RICHARD STANTON
articles.summary: The article "April Starry Nights" by Richard Stanton serves as an astronomical guide for April 1989, detailing various celestial events. It provides information on meteor showers like the Lyrids and Sigma Leonids, highlights an Io transit event, and encourages observation of minor planets. Additionally, it includes a comprehensive celestial calendar with lunar phases and visibility data for the nearer planets, complete with rise, transit, and set times.

articles.title: SOL
articles.summary: This document provides astronomical data for April, including ephemerides for asteroids Juno, Vesta, and Amphitrite, along with details on astronomical twilight and sidereal time. It also features a 'Deep Sky Challenge' to find the Eagle Nebula (IC 2177/NGC 2327) in Monoceros and introduces Gregg Thompson's 'Observing Site Darkness Scale' to standardize discussions on sky brightness for amateur astronomers.

articles.title: ASTRO ADS
articles.summary: ASTRO ADS is a free classifieds service for non-commercial advertisers to sell astronomically related products or services. Ads can be submitted to the Editor by the 15th of each month and run for approximately three months. Examples include listings for Celestron 8, Meade Quartz Motor Drive System, and Celestron Super C8 Plus telescopes and accessories.

articles.title: BY JIM VAN NULAND
articles.summary: This article, by Jim Van Nuland, announces the end of the Jupiter Great Red Spot observing season for 1989 due to the planet's declining altitude, providing a schedule of GRS meridian transit times for April and early May. The column will go on hiatus until late 1989. The document also includes a section of classified advertisements for various astronomical equipment, such as telescopes, mounts, accessories, and back issues of astronomy magazines.

articles.title: BY: BOB FINGERHUT
articles.summary: The article reports on several space-related developments, including the successful launch of Space Shuttle Discovery, which deployed the TDRS satellite and conducted various experiments, with Atlantis preparing for its next mission. It also details a temporary reprieve for the Landsat 4 and 5 satellites due to intervention by Vice President Dan Quayle and funding from data users. Additionally, Europe's Arianespace conducted its first launch of 1989, deploying two satellites, and NASA formed a group to develop future strategies for lunar exploration.

articles.title: DOUBLE, TRIPLE AND MULTIPLE STARS
articles.summary: This article serves as an observing guide to the constellation Leo, focusing on its wealth of double, triple, and multiple star systems. The author highlights several notable systems like Gamma Leonis (Algeiba) and Alpha Leonis (Regulus), providing magnitudes, separations, and personal observing notes. It also briefly recommends observing several galaxies in the Leo Galaxy Group after exploring the multiple stars.

articles.title: COMET COMMENTS
articles.summary: Don Machholz reports on recent comet activity, noting the recovery of two faint periodic comets, Pons-Winnecke (1989a) and Clark (1989h), by Jim Gibson. He also mentions comet Shoemaker-Holt-Rodriquez (1988h) brightening for Southern Hemisphere observers and highlights a significant period of comet discoveries and rediscoveries, by both amateurs and professionals, early in 1989.

articles.title: SEEKING COMETS
articles.summary: This article analyzes data from 45 visual comet discoveries between 1975 and 1988 to determine the typical timing of finds relative to astronomical twilight. It found that evening comet discoveries averaged 55.8 minutes after astronomical twilight and were widely scattered, while morning discoveries averaged 30.4 minutes before astronomical twilight and tended to cluster at the 20-minute mark. These differences are attributed to comets' movement in relation to the sun and their varying brightness as they become visible.

articles.title: Saturday, May 6, 1989
articles.summary: The article announces a special pre-season observing session for Northern California amateur astronomers on Saturday, May 6, 1989, at Fremont Peak. This free event offers access to a 30" telescope and dark sky sites, prior to the start of public programs, with camping available and refreshments provided.

articles.title: SAN JOSE ASTRONOMICAL ASSOCIATION MEMBERSHIP APPLICATION
articles.summary: This document is a membership application form for the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA). It outlines different membership options and their fees, including 'Membership only,' 'Membership/S&T,' and 'Junior,' and provides instructions for submitting the form via mail or in-person at an SJAA meeting.
